image.altText: A road with trees fallen over due to strong winds.

items.synopsis: Heavy rain in Victoria brings some relief to firefighters, but residents now face the threat of flash flooding, as emergency services respond to 300 calls for help.

title.children: Victorian towns welcome downpour after 'Armageddon' bushfires, but now face flood threat

image.altText: A roll cloud over the ocean

items.synopsis: Thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast for parts of Victoria and New South Wales, dousing fires but bringing the threat of flash flooding, as a low pressure system intensifies over the eastern states.

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: A massive plume of bushfire smoke looms above the hills beyond a country suburb.

items.synopsis: More hot, dry and windy conditions are expected to challenge fire crews today, but potential danger of a different kind is causing concern elsewhere in the state.

title.children: Homes lost as fires threaten NSW coast while inland residents face flood risk

image.altText: Uluru with question marks super imposed over it, clolourful splashes around in the sky.

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament is proposed to be an advisory body made up of First Nations people from across the country who will be able to advise on policies that affect them — but doesn't the government already have a few of those?

title.children: How different would the Voice be from other advisory bodies?

image.altText: A woman and her son sit on a bench near a tree in the sun.

items.synopsis: Nagorno-Karabakh is trapped in the eye of a swirling geopolitical storm of duelling world powers. For decades, Russia has played a role in mediating conflict around the enclave, but Azerbaijan’s move to take back the area has exposed Moscow's waning influence.

title.children: This conflict in Russia’s backyard has exposed Putin’s growing weakness

image.altText: A woman in a suit jacket stands at a lectern.

items.synopsis: A teenage girl and her family were "failed" by the state when she was allegedly raped by a male patient in the mental health ward of Perth Children's Hospital in January last year, Western Australia's Health Minister, Amber-Jade Sanderson has admitted.

title.children: 'I feel like I'm being gaslit': Parents of young girl allegedly raped in children's hospital respond to health minister

image.altText: Flowers next to a tree with a police car in the background

items.synopsis: A road toll rise in parts of Australia has experts worried that we are going backwards on road safety.

title.children: 'Giving the middle finger to common sense': Are Australia's roads getting more dangerous?

image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent for a fourth month at its meeting on Tuesday. Here's what it means for inflation, and whether rate cuts are on the horizon.

title.children: The Reserve Bank left rates unchanged again. Does it mean rate cuts are on the horizon?

image.altText: An armed man kneels on the floor next to a person who is lying on the floor with their hands behind their back, inside a shop

items.synopsis: Thai police say they have arrested a 14-year-old boy after a fatal shooting at Thailand's most famous shopping mall.

title.children: Teenager allegedly carries out fatal shooting in luxury Bangkok shopping mall

image.altText: A man with a grey beard wearing a yes shirt smiling outside a early polling centre

items.synopsis: Almost half a million Australians have headed to pre-poll stations casting early votes in the upcoming referendum.

title.children: Yes campaigners say they are fighting to beat 'misinformation' before voters get to the ballot box

image.altText: A close up of Daniel Andrews and other politicians.

items.synopsis: Lawyers the Victorian government hired to negotiate the cancellation of the Commonwealth Games weeks before it officially made the announcement cost taxpayers more than $1 million, documents show.

title.children: Lawyers hired weeks before Commonwealth Games cancellation announcement, documents show

image.altText: Passengers at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: Experts say capacity on regional and international flights have not returned to pre-pandemic levels and are keeping airfares high.

title.children: Flight prices still remain high after COVID, but some tickets are much more expensive than others

image.altText: Vacharaesorn Vivacharawongse holding his hands together in a Thai wai gesture.

items.synopsis: The conviction and sentencing of a human rights lawyer and activist last week under Thailand's lese-majeste law — the first since the country's new government took office — has left those pushing for reform of the law dismayed, but experts believe there is reason to hope for change in the longer term.

title.children: Does hope to change Thailand's royal insult law lie with the king's estranged son?

image.altText: A packet of sour candy in rainbow colour

items.synopsis: The Caribbean country's education minister says students at Ochos Rios Primary School in St Ann were taken to hospital following the incident.

title.children: More than 60 Jamaican primary schoolers in hospital after eating rainbow cannabis candy

image.altText: A man ina full body yellow suit and protective gear lights some wild grass on fire.

items.synopsis: Human error has been blamed for an incorrect tally of the number of hazard reduction burns carried out in Queensland.

title.children: Queensland's fire chief mistakenly provided incorrect hazard reduction figure ahead of bushfire season, announces resignation

image.altText: A bar and staff with customers in a nightclub with red walls.

items.synopsis: A Hobart nightclub bouncer did not act in self-defence when he punched an ejected patron, who now needs 24-hour care for mental and physical disabilities, a court finds.

title.children: Man awarded $12m after being left with disabilities following nightclub bouncer's punch

image.altText: Marc Polmans hits a forehand.

items.synopsis: He may not be as well-known as Nick Kyrgios, but Marc Polmans has managed to do something his superstar compatriot has never done in any angry outburst at the chair umpire.

title.children: Australian tennis player smashes umpire in the face with ball, gets disqualified

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell of Australia plays a shot during the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup India 2023 warm up match.

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell again reminds the cricket world just how devastating he can be as Australian tune up for the ODI World Cup with a win over Pakistan.

title.children: Maxwell stars again as Australia defeat Pakistan in final World Cup warm-up

image.altText: Hunter Biden's has a neutral expression. He's wearing a dark jacket and tie with a white shirt.

items.synopsis: Joe Biden's only living son becomes the first child of a sitting US president to be arraigned on felony charges, pleading not guilty in a Delaware court.

title.children: Joe Biden's son faces serious gun charges. Here are the key points from today's court hearing

image.altText: A composite image of an older man with white hair, and a cream brick building with an ornate veranda.

items.synopsis: William Arnott emigrated from Scotland in the 1840s and went on to build a biscuit empire in his new homeland. His first bakehouse in Morpeth is still operating, but it's not biscuits coming out of the woodfired oven these days.

title.children: It's 175 years since William Arnott first made biscuits in this small-town bakery — and it's still running today

image.altText: A greyhound in a kennel.

items.synopsis: As a former greyhound adoption worker speaks out about what she witnessed during her time in the industry, an MP releases what she described as "graphic and concerning and disturbing" photos of emaciated dogs and squalid kennels. Warning: This story contains content that may distress some readers.

title.children: Greyhound mistreatment concerns trigger release of 'concerning and disturbing' photos in parliament

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: The transport minister says a request for her to front an inquiry examining the decision to reject Qatar Airways from expanding its services in Australia is a political stunt, and a waste of her time.

title.children: 'Time wasting': Transport minister rebuffs request to front airlines inquiry

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses and a hijab.

items.synopsis: As a long, sweltering summer looms, Melbourne's public housing residents are yet to see any sign of air conditioners promised before last year's state election.

title.children: When Ayan sees hot weather forecast, she packs up and leaves her public housing flat to protect her health

image.altText: A young man in a suit leans against a bridge over a body of water.

items.synopsis: A new report says international graduates are being given false hope for permanent residency pathways, and calls for an overhaul of post-work rights, saying visas have become "too generous".

title.children: Are international students' post-study work rights 'too generous'?

image.altText: An older woman with a dark grey bob and glasses speaks into a small microphone in front of a blue screen.

items.synopsis: Petrol prices have pushed inflation up. At its next meeting, the RBA board is going to have to decide if that warrants an increase in interest rates, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Petrol prices have pushed up inflation — and they could lead to an interest rate hike next month

image.altText: A speed sign on the side of a country road. Its numerals have been altered with tape so that it reads "No".

items.synopsis: Speed signs altered to read "No" have been spotted in SA, sparking safety concerns and a police investigation.

title.children: Multiple speed signs defaced as early voting for the Voice gets underway

image.altText: A circle of rocks surrounding a hole in the ground in an outback paddock.

items.synopsis: Police say they are investigating the apparent desecration of the cultural heritage site, which has hurt and angered the area's Aboriginal custodians.

title.children: 'Another insult' as Indigenous well filled with concrete in outback Queensland

image.altText: Melbourne Demons AFLW player Libby Birch has a look of concentration after executing a handball in a game

items.synopsis: AFLW player Libby Birch wants more women to feel comfortable talking about their breasts, while more options are now available to help those playing contact sport avoid injury.

title.children: Finding the right fit: Why breasts are a still a 'taboo' topic in sport, and what we can do to protect them

image.altText: Celtic soccer player Tom Rogic smiles as he holds his daughter next to a woman, with a large trophy in front of them.

items.synopsis: Socceroos playmaker Tom Rogic announces his retirement from football and says he and his wife's fertility issues and a desire to focus on his family are a key factor in his decision.

title.children: Socceroos star Tom Rogic announces his retirement from football

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

items.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear
